content.apps module

class content.apps.ContentConfig(app_name, app_module)

Bases: AppConfig

default_auto_field = 'django.db.models.BigAutoField'
name = 'content'
ready()

This function sets the signals. It is needed to call the signals for the tasks like creating the new video resolution files, which then run in the background with an rq-worker.

content.functions module

content.functions.get_category_videos(categories)

This function goes through the videos and returns all categories.

content.functions.get_latest_video()

This function gets the newest video on the database and serializes it.

content.functions.get_latest_views()

This function gets the 6 latest videos and serializes them.

content.functions.get_my_videos(request)

This function gets the videos the user has partly watched and serializes them.

content.functions.get_selected_video(video_id)

This function gets the video for the her section and serializes it.

content.functions.get_video(video_id, user, resolution)

This function gets the video the user picks and serializes it.

hls_file_1080

The descriptor for the file attribute on the model instance. Return a FieldFile when accessed so you can write code like:

>>> from myapp.models import MyModel
>>> instance = MyModel.objects.get(pk=1)
>>> instance.file.size

Assign a file object on assignment so you can do:

>>> with open('/path/to/hello.world') as f:
...     instance.file = File(f)

thumbnail

Just like the FileDescriptor, but for ImageFields. The only difference is assigning the width/height to the width_field/height_field, if appropriate.

A wrapper for a deferred-loading field. When the value is read from this object the first time, the query is executed.

watchhistory_set

Accessor to the related objects manager on the reverse side of a many-to-one relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

content.models.thumbnail_upload_to(instance, filename)

This function removes all empty spaces and replaces them with underscores. Then it creates the new path.

content.models.video_upload_to(instance, filename)

This function removes all empty spaces and replaces them with underscores. Then it creates the new path.

model

alias of Video

get_hls_file(obj)

This function the HLS file depending on the given resolution.

get_timestamp(obj)

This function gets the timestamp of the video based on the video and the user. If there is no timestamp the function returns 0.

content.signals module

content.signals.thumbnail_post_delete(sender, instance, **kwargs)

This function starts the deletion of the thumbnail.

content.signals.video_post_delete(sender, instance, **kwargs)

This starts the deletion of the video folder.

content.signals.video_post_save(sender, instance, created, **kwargs)

This function queues the creation of the HLS files to a rq-worker.

content.tasks module

content.tasks.convert(source, folder_path)

This function converts a video file into the desired HLS files. It is called as a signal so it can run in the background.

content.tasks.convert_to_hls(source, output_name_prefix)

This function converts an input file to a specified HLS file.

content.tasks.convert_to_resolution(source, output_name, resolution)

This function uses the FFmpeg tool to convert a video file to a specified resolution.

content.tasks.create_output_directory(sanitized_folder_path)

This function creates the output directory for the HLS files based on the name of the video file.

content.tasks.delete_mp4(resolution_file)

This function deletes the mp4 file that is created for creating the HLS files.

content.tasks.delete_thumbnail_folder(folder_path)

This function deletes the thumbnail folder if a user deletes a video in the admin panel.

content.tasks.delete_video_folder(folder_path)

This function deletes the video folder if a user deletes a video in the admin panel.

content.tasks.process_resolution(video_instance, source, base_name, output_dir, suffix, field_name, resolution)

This function starts the process of starts the creation of the the HLS files. In the end it deletes the helper mp4 file.

content.tests module

content.views module

class content.views.DashboardView(**kwargs)

Bases: APIView

dispatch(request, *args, **kwargs)

.dispatch() is pretty much the same as Django’s regular dispatch, but with extra hooks for startup, finalize, and exception handling.

get(request)

This function returns the data for the dashboard. It gets the 6 latest videos, the videos the user has watched, all the categories and the videos sorted by categories.

class content.views.HeroView(**kwargs)

Bases: APIView

dispatch(request, *args, **kwargs)

.dispatch() is pretty much the same as Django’s regular dispatch, but with extra hooks for startup, finalize, and exception handling.

get(request)

This function returns the data for the hero area. If the user is new on the page, the latest video is returned, else the selected video.

class content.views.VideoView(**kwargs)

Bases: APIView

dispatch(request, *args, **kwargs)

.dispatch() is pretty much the same as Django’s regular dispatch, but with extra hooks for startup, finalize, and exception handling.

get(request)

This function returns the video data for the actual video the user wants to watch. It returns the m3u8 file based on the given resolution.
